title: Bartz v Anthropic
headline: Bartz v Anthropic - rules AI training fair use.
summary:
Summaries: Bartz v Anthropic — Anthropic pays the largest known copyright settlement in history! 2 weeks ago, we saw that the Bartz plaintiffs (book authors and rights-holders) and Anthropic had reached a proposed settlement, but we did not know any of the terms. Last Friday, the world found out that the proposed settlement is $1.5 Billion! There are roughly 500,000 copyrighted works subject to the settlement, resulting is about $3,000 per work. Although this is certainly an historic and watershed moment in AI training litigation, we need to put it in context. And, today is the day Judge Alsup is expected to approve the settlement. Recall that Judge Alsup’s summary judgment ruling didn’t fault Anthropic for training its AI on copyrighted works. Rather, Alsup found that pirating copyrighted works to create a general-purpose digital library for Anthropic to use however it wanted was not “fair use.” In another case decided that same week several weeks ago, Judge Vince Chhabria (in the same federal district) ruled that Meta’s acquisition of copyrighted materials through torrenting was not copyright infringement because the purpose of the acquisition was to train an AI system, which both Chhabria and Alsup found to be fair use. According to Alsup, Anthropic’s violation here is not training its AI, but taking hundreds of thousands of copyrighted works for whatever purpose it wanted. Arguably, if Anthropic had simply purchased the copyrighted works (likely for far less than $3,000 a copy) it would have been clear to train its AI however it chose — although, to be clear, Judge Chhabria would likely reach a different result. It remains to be seen how or whether courts will try to synthesize Judge Chhabria’s ruling in Kadrey with Alsup’s ruling in Bartz . But for now, the Bartz authors can claim a well-earned victory. Despite the complex background, we remain hopeful that this massive settlement will encourage other AI companies to compensate authors for the use of their copyrighted works. And we expect they will.

Key takeaway: Historic settlement magnitude (~$1.5B) signals heavy liability where acquisition of works was unauthorized.

title: Concord Music Group, et al. v Anthropic
headline: Concord Music Group, et al. v Anthropic
summary: Summaries: Concord Music Group, et al. v Anthropic — Bartz continues to haunt Anthropic. A few weeks ago, Anthropic submitted an opposition to Plaintiffs’ motion seeking leave to amend its complaint, adding claims related to the torrenting of copyrighted work as well as several additional works. Plaintiffs’ likely seek to recreate some of the success seen by the Bartz plaintiffs in another case involving Anthropic. Anthropic has argued that this belated amendment should be disallowed. Last week, Plaintiffs submitted their reply brief supporting their motion to amend in which they argued that any delay in bringing these claims was attributable to discovery failures by Anthropic. The parties also submitted a joint discovery dispute statement regarding what Anthropic has called deficient damages disclosures by Plaintiffs. Plaintiffs also filed a motion to compel the production of the evidence related to torrenting that was produced in the Bartz case, arguing that “there is no question that Publishers’ lyrics are included in the 7 million books that Anthropic illegally downloaded.” Plaintiffs also ask for unredacted versions of briefing from Bartz .

title: Disney et al. v Midjourney
headline: Disney et al. v Midjourney
summary: Summaries: Disney et al. v Midjourney — No major substantive developments this past week . As we reported two weeks ago, the most recent movement was Midjourney’s answer where Midjourney likened the process of training an LLM to the process of a human being learning, echoing the reasoning underlying the fair use defenses of other AI companies. At the same time, Midjourney described its product as a tool used by artists. Midjourney suggested that, to the extent that any produced images infringed Disney’s copyrights, they were only created at the instruction of its users. Midjourney raised a particularly interesting affirmative defense: unclean hands. Apparently Disney’s own purported use of training an AI model on copyrighted works precludes Disney from enforcing its own copyrights. We suspect that the unclean hands defense may be more marketing than lawyering, but we’ll see.

title: Dow Jones & Co, et al v Perplexity AI
headline: Dow Jones & Co, et al v Perplexity AI - dismisses AI/IP claims.
summary: Summaries: Dow Jones & Co, et al v Perplexity AI — Going into deep freeze. It has been several months since Plaintiffs submitted their memorandum of law opposing Defendant’s motion to dismiss or transfer the case. We’re going to put this case on the back burner until there is some substantial movement on the docket.

title: Getty Images v Midjourney et al.
headline: Getty Images v Midjourney et al.
summary: Summaries: Getty Images v Midjourney et al. — Still no update for Getty . With no notable updates for Getty in over a third of a year, this case on the back-burner. As a final update on where we last left off: Getty had submitted a letter to the Court on November 25th, 2024 explaining its frustration with Stability AI’s refusal to participate in discovery or participate in a Rule 26(f) conference. In August 2024, Stability AI had argued that they were under no obligation to commence fact discovery until the Court issued its ruling on jurisdiction. Getty had requested that the Court order Stability to stop delaying and proceed with the case, but after several months with no response from the Court, it appears unclear when things will begin moving forward again.

title: Kadrey et al. v Meta
headline: Kadrey et al. v Meta
summary: Summaries: Kadrey et al. v Meta — Judge Chhabria charts a course to summary judgment on copying and uploading of books . In the aftermath of Meta’s success on summary judgment regarding the use of books as training data, Plaintiffs have continued to litigate issues related to the distribution of pirated books by Meta in the course of torrenting them. Two weeks ago, the parties managed to agree on an expert discovery schedule, though they were unable to agree on a schedule for summary judgment briefing. This past Friday, Judge Chhabria adopted the parties’ proposed deadlines and set summary judgment briefing to begin about a week later, with the hearing set for February 12th next year.

title: Reddit v Anthropic
headline: Reddit v Anthropic
summary: Summaries: Reddit v Anthropic — The parties fight over removal. This case has been removed to the Northern District of California after it was originally filed in California state court. Reddit was expected to file a motion to remand the case to state court on October 29th, which it did. Its motion argued that its claims involved non-copyright components which prevented pre-emption and that, even if the Court found some preemption, the Court should not exercise supplemental jurisdiction over the remaining causes of action. We expect the federal court may hold on to this one, but we will report back whenever we find out.

title: Sarah Andersen v Stability AI
headline: Sarah Andersen v Stability AI - dismisses AI/IP claims.
summary:
Summaries: Sarah Andersen v Stability AI — Dr. Zhao is still out. The Plaintiffs’ long battle to use Dr. Zhao as an expert may finally be over. The Court denied Plaintiffs’ motion to overturn the “very thorough” order by Magistrate Judge Cisneros denying Dr. Zhao permission to view confidential material as Plaintiffs’ expert. Check back next week to see where the parties take their dispute now that this issue has been decided with finality.

Key takeaway: Claims that don’t connect copying to cognizable market harm risk dismissal.

title: SDNY Multi-District Litigation
headline: SDNY Multi-District Litigation - dismisses AI/IP claims.
summary: Summaries: SDNY Multi-District Litigation — The parties exchange discovery salvos . The last two weeks brought several discovery motions between the MDL parties. Ziff Davis filed its reply memorandum of law opposing OpenAI’s motion to dismiss. OpenAI has alleged that Ziff Davis’ robots.txt (includes information to inform web crawlers of whether a site owner permits scraping) was not a sufficient technological measure to give rise to a DMCA claim. OpenAI also argued that Ziff Davis’ unjust enrichment claims were preempted and that its trademark claims were not sufficiently plead. Ziff Davis maintained that its claims regarding circumvention of its robots.txt configuration were actionable under the DMCA; that its unjust enrichment claims involved non-copyright interests, avoiding pre-emption; and that it had sufficiently alleged the fame of its trademarks to establish a claim of trademark infringement. OpenAI and Microsoft also filed reply briefs in support of their motions to strike portions of the class plaintiffs’ complaint. They contend that the addition of models other than GPT-3, GPT-3.5, GPT-4, and GPT-4 Turbo is improper and that the case should be limited to the originally-plead models. Additionally, they argue that the addition of copyright claims based on the downloading of copyrighted materials (rather than their use for model training) should be disallowed. Finally, the class plaintiffs filed a motion seeking in camera review of a number of OpenAI documents, arguing that they were improperly withheld as privileged. Though the motion is heavily redacted, it is evident that the class plaintiffs are challenging whether these documents served the primary purpose of obtaining legal advice in order for work product privilege to attach. OpenAI has also filed a reply opposing the class plaintiffs’ motion.

title: The New York Times v Microsoft et al.
headline: The New York Times v Microsoft et al.
summary: Summaries: The New York Times v Microsoft et al. — OpenAI objects to preservation order. As we discussed previously, the Court has maintained its order for OpenAI to preserve chat logs that would otherwise be deleted under its privacy policies, citing concerns that the same users who might use ChatGPT to circumvent The New York Times ’ paywall protections would be more likely to request deletion of their chat logs. OpenAI has maintained its objections to this order. In its Objection to Preservation Order, OpenAI raised three main arguments. First, that the preservation order does not serve a useful purpose because the idea that certain users attempt to “cover their tracks” is far-fetched. Second, they argued that the Order is not proportional to the needs of the case, because it would require OpenAI to make infrastructural changes to support the retention and would strain user trust in OpenAI. Finally, OpenAI argued that the preservation order was based on false premises, stating that OpenAI did not “destroy” any data, and certainly did not delete any data in response to litigation events. OpenAI’s false-premises argument cites support from a non-public declaration, but it appears that OpenAI may be relying on a narrow distinction between “deleting” data (which it is arguing is needed to maintain customer trust) and “destroying” data which the News Plaintiffs could argue gives rise to adverse inference.

title: Thomson Reuters v Ross Intelligence
headline: Thomson Reuters v Ross Intelligence - rules AI training fair use.
summary: Summaries: Thomson Reuters v Ross Intelligence — We are still awaiting the “fair use” determination by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, after the federal district court had certified Ross’ fair-use and copyrightability arguments for interlocutory appeal. On April 4th, the federal district court judge granted Ross Intelligence’ motion for interlocutory appeal off the Court’s summary judgment ruling against Ross’ “fair use” and copyrightability arguments. The Court stated that “Though I remain confident in my February 2025 summary judgment opinion, I recognize that there are substantial ground for difference of opinion on controlling legal issues in this case.” The two questions certified are “ (1) whether the West headnotes and West Key Number System are original; and (2) whether Ross’s use of the headnotes was fair use.” We’re not particularly surprised at this development. The country is watching this case rather closely because of its proximity to the generative AI training cases, and the hundreds of billions of dollars at stake there. Trying the case without considering the certified questions, and then having those issues reversed on appeal could waste everyone’s resources.

title: UMG Recordings v Suno
headline: UMG Recordings v Suno
summary: Summaries: UMG Recordings v Suno — No major substantive developments this past week . we discussed months ago, the Court adopted the parties’ joint stipulation and proposed order stipulating that digital copies of the works would suffice as deposit copies. Though the parties have continued discovery in the background, this has resulted in relatively few filings.

title: UMG Recordings v Uncharted Labs
headline: UMG Recordings v Uncharted Labs
summary: Summaries: UMG Recordings v Uncharted Labs — No major substantive developments this past week . The docket in his case has seen very little development in the past months. However, the parties have agreed to an extension of time for document production, pushing the completion date out to October 10th.

title: Warner Bros. Discovery v Midjourney
headline: Warner Bros. Discovery v Midjourney - dismisses AI/IP claims.
summary: Summaries: Warner Bros. Discovery v Midjourney — Warner Bros. Discovery joins the fight against Midjourney! On September 4th, Warner Bros. Discovery sued Midjourney in the United States District Court for the Central District of California alleging direct and secondary copyright infringement. The complaint is similar in many ways to Disney and Universal’s showing dozens of strikingly similar images where Midjourney’s outputs mimic Warner Bros. copyrighted characters. The fact that Warner Bros. also picked Midjourney as a sole target speaks volumes about Midjourney’s uniquely dismissive attitude towards copyright and generative AI. The next step will be for Midjourney to file an answer or other responsive pleading. We expect an answer from Midjourney will track the answer in the case against Disney and Universal, claiming fair use and that it does not control what its users create. Three of the “Big Five” studios have now sued Midjourney, leaving only Sony and Paramount on the sidelines. We will see if they follow suit.
